item.title: Quotes and thoughts I grew up with........
item.dc:creator: farajackus
item.content:encoded:
In my early years of life, I had few people who inspired and gave me the sense of having ethics and values. To start with, it was my maternal grandparents. Unfortunately for me, my paternal grandparents were gone way before I was born. I have just heard stories of my paternal grandma being an absolute sweetheart, a very loving and caring person. 

Amma (Maternal Grandma)

 She is the one who introduced me to Quran at an early age in a way that I started to enjoy reading it. She once told me that " Haq baat karne ke liye chota ya bada hone ki zarurath nahi, sahi hona zaroori hai." which means that you can voice out your opinion irrespective of your position, you just need to be righteous.

Abba (My Father)

I lost him on 10th March 2020, and ever since have missed him in every possible way. He was the one who brought in a lot of discipline in my life. Though I used to feel that he was being too harsh on us. Later I realized that he was laying a strong foundation in my life. There are a couple of things he has instilled in me. Some values that will remain with me forever.

Two of my favorite ones are he asked me to always respect my roots and never forget the state with which we have started our lives. In his opinion, respecting our roots is a way of staying grounded. And the second one is his emphasis on us being strong. He had a Doctorate Degree in Urdu Literature. So he used to quote the below poetry from Allama Iqbal

" Khudi ko kar buland itna ke har taqder se pehle

Khuda bande se ye poche bata teri raza kya hai"

which means " Raise yourself to such great heights so, before every destined act, God himself asks what is it you desire."

Ammi (My Mom)

She is an extremely energetic and a dotting mother. There is always one thing she is known for, is her compassion. Once I questioned her as to why would she care so much for every person around us despite having a job, family, and a tight schedule. She then said something that I want to live up to my entire life. She said " Living for someone you live, living for yourself is like death."

And of course, there were a lot of teachers and relatives who have loved and inspired me a lot. This is just a small sneak peek into my childhood.

Thank you for your patience.

Love and Peace.

item.title: Summer holidays while in school.
item.dc:creator: farajackus
item.content:encoded:
The most joyous times of my life as a kid in school, when we had our summer holidays. That was the time we would go to our Nani's place. So this gave us chance to experience staying in a small town. And fortunately for us, our Nanu and some of our relatives had farms in that town. We would go bonkers during this time, as we had maximum liberty.

Unlike kids these days, who are glued to screens for games. We had all of it in nature. It was a small town, where you could get bikes on rent, run and hop around and build castles in the sand while we also used to play with natural clay. We also build trucks with cardboard and other things available.

But the best part was going to the Farmhouse. We had long swings hanging from huge mango trees, water gushing out of huge pipes and we had a small tank at the end of these pipes. Where we would jump around and have fun. We could drink sweet coconut water all day. And run around the farm. We also tried feeding the cattle along with the caretakers. And also used to have a lot of mangoes. Here, let me specify the way we used to eat mangoes. Now, all the mangoes that were ripe and good to eat were put into a bucket full of water. And we used to eat mangoes without cutting them, which made the mangoes tastier for us.

But we had Ammi (my mother) there who used to try to keep us on track by having us complete our holiday homework. And disciplining us to maintain our routine. And 50% of the time she also used to be successful. I'm so grateful that I have such wonderful memories of my childhood. I hope you enjoyed reading this blog and remembered your childhood too.

Love and Peace

item.title: An Attitude Of Gratitude......
item.dc:creator: farajackus
item.content:encoded:
This topic may seem common, but has been very effective over years. Always be happy and grateful for all that you have today. You may argue saying that all this is easy to say, but hard when your facing your daily grind. My simple solution for this is writing a gratitude list.

You may think how can just jotting down few things that make me feel happy matter. But I challenge you to give it a try and see the results for yourself When you start being grateful, you automatically start looking for positivity. This helps you from preventing yourself to feel mentally and emotionally drained.

Now, let me give a scientific explanation, gratitude can boost neurotransmitter serotonin and activate the brain stem to produce dopamine. Dopamine is our brain's pleasure chemical. The more we think positively about grateful thoughts, the healthier and happier we feel.

If your a believer who goes by the sacred books then let me give you some context too.

" So remember Me; I will remember you. Be thankful to Me, and never ungrateful." - Quran 2:152.

"Give thanks in all circumstances; for this is the will of God in Christ Jesus for you."

Bible Thessalonians 5:18.

The word for Gratitude is ktaja - which means recognizing favors that have been done

Lack of gratitude (ktaghnam) is said to be the worst sin of all, for which there is no expatriation.

ktaghna mahptaka ditam - Garua Pura 1,52.24

ktaghne nsti nikti there is no expiation for the ungrateful one. - Kish. 34:12.

So I strongly believe in having an attitude of gratitude as that gives you great satisfaction and inner peace. This in turn helps you be 100% productive. At the same time, I don't claim to be perfect, there are times when I'm feeling low. When you feel so you must constantly remind yourself to be grateful.

Thanks for reading......

Love and Peace.

item.title: Love my ethnicity
item.dc:creator: farajackus
item.content:encoded:
It is indeed an awesome feeling when you realise that your so much in love with your own ethnicity. Thanks to all my elders who introduced me to our culture in a way that I grew fondness for it. I'm always able to relate to being a kannadiga (person who stays in Karnataka), no matter how global I tend to grow.

Things like eating idli sambar or dosa on most of our mornings; wearing flowers in my hair(mallige moggu); to still remember kannada poems from school, written by Kuvempu, Nisar Ahmed or Basavanna; vividly remembering the state anthem; eating yallu bella and kajjaya for Sankranti. All of these have become a part of me and today I can proudly call myself "mannina magalu" (daughter of the land). I feel patriotism is an acquired value, which will grow strong if it has been acquired early in one's life. And I strongly feel connected to my land.

When I'm giving you context about my cultural background, please don't mistake me to be a biased narrow minded person. I strongly believe in inclusiveness. I believe that we all are global citizens. And that we can have strong belief system in our lives while we respect and tolerate other's belief system. This is important for a healthy, safe and a happy World.

How can we have inclusiveness in our culture?

A billion dollar question in today's date as we all have started working with people from all over the world. And we can have enormous growth only when we have inclusiveness. My answer to the above question is bygiving respect, a brief understanding of their culture and empathy towards people( irrespective of the geographical area they belong).

Last but not the least, a fun fact the girl with flowers in the above photograph is me.

item.title: Flaws Make You Real.
item.dc:creator: farajackus
item.content:encoded:
There have been a lot of times when we look at ourselves in the mirror and feel disgusted about our physical appearance. Or think about some embarrassing moments during our weak times and try to hide them. We only concentrate on our strengths and don't want to do anything about our flaws. By doing so, we are just deceiving ourselves. Accepting flaws as a part of life and working on them is a realistic goal that is necessary.

Let me tell you about an instance just after I got married. We stayed together with our in-laws and used to have a lot of conversations. Once, Abbu (my father-in-law) told me that flaws and imperfections in our life are needed to make us complete beings. He gave me the example of jewelry. He said people make such beautiful jewelry by adding impurities to pure gold. That was the first time it occurred to me that flaws are supposed to be accepted. And there was no need to feel disgusted about them.

And later I also understood that after accepting our flaws, we need to work on them. But this requires a lot of patience and self-love. We need to understand the fact that everybody sins differently. And that you are not alone. There is no need to talk about your flaws to anybody, but being mindful of them is a good start. Then instead of suppressing them and avoiding them totally, trying to moderate them can be helpful. Get feedback from people who wish good for you and try to work on it. Once you can do that, you can slowly control them. But failing to do so can put you into a loop of things that can lead you to self-destruction.

Appreciate your patience. Love and Peace.

item.title: Marriage Fiesta....
item.dc:creator: farajackus
item.content:encoded:
It amazes me to even think that our relationship, Alhamdulillah!!! is almost about to become a teenager next month. Little did we know, that our acquaintance would turn into deep friendship, lead us into marriage and then blissful parenthood.

Irrespective of how you might have met your spouse, he/she is your partner with whom you go through this adventure called LIFE. How you feel about this relationship, is never consistent nor simple to define. It feels like a roller coaster ride. A lot of ups and downs. You could also be falling in and out of love. The feelings we have in this relationship may be the most complex one. No matter how long you stay together, you can't really draw a pattern around this relationship. And, unfortunately there are a lot of couples who realise that they are better off without each other. And they break up.

It's human to not feel the same all the time. And differences are bound to happen as we are two different people with different opinions trying to partner almost everything in our lives. It is a concious decision for both of us to stay together when there are numerous distractions and temptations in the world. It really takes a lot of effort and dedication to accept each other's flaws and leverage the strengths. And choosing righteous, smart and logical people to councel you when you are in doubt about your marriage, is critical. And alsokeeping the communication on can prevent unnecessary misunderstandings. Most importantly to understand that we don't own each other. Giving each other a non judgemental safe space, in a way that they don't hesitate to talk about their deepest or the most embarrassing secrets. Letting them remain unchanged and raw in their nature, while nurturing them to get better, and respecting each other's boundaries is the key to keep that relationship going even during the tough times. Let your children not be the only reason you choose to stay together. Rather let your children feel that you both are together because you value each other and want to build this warm little nest of ours. We could be completing 13 years of our marriage next month, but we are still constantly working towards making it work every single day. We don't claim to be perfect at any stage of our marriage, it's just the efforts that keeps us together.

For someone who is a believer, there are some beautiful verses in the sacred books that really helps us in solving this riddle called marriage. Let me quote just few of them, here.

" They are clothing for you and you are clothing for them. " - Quran (2: 187)

This verse from Quran explains how we are suppose to hide our spouse's flaws from the world.

Above all, love each other deeply, because love covers over a multitude of sins. - 1 Peter 4:8 

This verse from Bible tells us how to forgive and love our spouse unconditionally.

kimsvin mitram grheshesataha?    bhaaryaa mitram grhesataha 

This is a verse from Rig ved, Yudhishtiras answer to the question indicates the Hindu belief that friendship between a couple is the true basis for the marital union.

To sum it up, it definitely takes you, to fall in love with your best friend in different ways and multiple times to keep the spark in your marriage. While you have each other's back irrespective of the flaws or mistakes. If both of you have a honest and a forgiving heart, you can always get things back on track. But I strongly recommend that you be smart enough to differentiate between making mistakes and having a toxic relationship. If it's a mistake you both can always work on it, but if it's a toxic relationship your better off without it.

Last but not the least, hoping and praying that God blesses each one of us with his choicest blessings and helps us lead a healthy and a righteous life. Love and peace

item.title: You can't Blend In, If You were Born to Stand Out.
item.dc:creator: farajackus
item.content:encoded:
When I was a little kid, I remember once when I was having a conversation with my cousins. I spoke to them about my plans and aspirations. It felt a little far-fetched then because we were just little kids at school. But I remember one of my cousins telling me that "you can accomplish all that you want." Somehow that thought struck my mind. I have realized a lot of my aspirations, yet working hard on realizing a lot of them. I'm able to relate to the poem by Mirza Ghalib. Which goes like this.....

"Hazaaron khwahishen aisi ke har khwahish pe dam nikle

Bahut niklay mere armaan, lekin phir bhi kam nikle."

Which means 

"Thousands of desires, each worth dying for

many of them I have realized, yet I yearn for more."

I believe a person without aspirations is not alive. Regardless of the success rate, people should never stop believing in themselves and their dreams. But, we get distracted by things that are not in our control. I'm referring to people's reactions, opinions, and approvals. It happens a lot of times to most of us. And we end up being self-critical, having self-doubt, lowering our boundaries to accommodate people, etc.

People tend to behave this way when they are not confident enough to accept themselves the way they are naturally. And it also needs a lot of effort to live life on our terms. We have to agree that we are different and celebrate it while respecting each other. And when we understand that there is no need to compromise ourselves just to be accepted by people, we then mentally reach a dangerous level of freedom.

item.title: Behind every strong Daughter, there is an Amazing Father.
item.dc:creator: farajackus
item.content:encoded:
Ever imagined, what would have been the feeling of your parents when they first saw you???? As a daughter, I feel lucky and blessed to read what my Abba ( my father) had felt when he first saw me in his journal.

He was an Urdu scholar, hence had used some complicated words to express his feelings. And I had to use a dictionary to understand the passage. Tears are rolling down my cheeks while I write about him, as two years back today, is when he left all of us. He referred to me as "Naayaab Toufa" (a precious gift) and as a divine blessing. He writes that it was difficult for him to contain himself, as he held me in his hands.

He was always a strict father as I was growing up. Be it sleeping at 8:30 pm to scoring good grades in school. He wanted no compromises in anything that we did in our life. He used to teach Shariya (Islamic way of life). But at times he was overprotective. I still remember he was hesitant to get me a bike when I was in my 10th standard. So, I purposely walked back home from school one day. And I managed to do it at the same time when he was returning from the University. When he asked, "why was I walking home, and where is the rickshaw ? ". I made a puppy face with big eyes and said I have special classes, so the rickshaw left, all my friends went home on their bikes. The next day he got me a brand new bike with gears, the best one available in the market.

But as I grew, he sometimes let me do things on my own. He did a lot of running around and got my admission into the best college in the city. He bought me a two-wheeler(Luna) and took me to a ground(Bal Bhawan in Mysore). He sat behind me and guided me to ride the bike. The second time, he tricked me into believing that he was right behind me. And, I took a long ride. Then I noticed him standing far away, waving at me and telling me that "I'm doing great, just continue."Abba,you just did the same thing, taught us to be strong and live our lives on our terms. You tricked us into believing that you would always be around and left us.

He made phone calls to all his colleagues at various festivals irrespective of their background. Abba was my first teacher who taught us about inclusiveness, compassion, and tolerance to others' belief systems. Jazakallah Khair Abba, for teaching us to be strong, honest, and humble. Insha Allah, I hope to live up to your expectations, Abba. May Allah give you the highest ranks in Jannah. Miss you terribly........

item.title: Mother !!!! By choice, not obligation.
item.dc:creator: farajackus
item.content:encoded:
Motherhood is walking around with all of your nerve endings raw and exposed. It is the most extreme measure of being alive. It feels surreal when you see that little heart go lub, lub, lub. During your ultrasound scan, while you are expecting your little one. I remember my husband held my hand and shouted with joy, and we were almost tearing up.

Life feels the way we want it to feel. It is all about our perception. Yes, you feel stressed and have sleepless nights with busy days. But all of that is nothing compared to the endless joy these little angels bring into our lives. And the best part is you get to keep them in your heart for the rest of your lives. It is a pleasure to watch them while you are trying to give them the best possible ambiance.

While they may be looking up to us as a point of reference, when we are just trying to be our best. Sometimes we forget that we are also growing up. And there is no need for us to stop living our dreams. I feel the best way to raise kids is to show that we had them by choice while we also enjoyed our lives. And that it was not one big sacrifice. That gives kids a feel-good factor. It helps them grow into confident people in the future.

Almost all the scared books go on and on about Mother's prominence. But as a mother, I want to express my feelings towards our kids. They bring so much joy into our lives that we often forget the hectic or bad days we might have faced. To have them run around is like watching your heartbeat outside of you. Masha Allah, those giggles, smiles, and quality moments make your life worth living. We are not doing them any favor by taking care of them. We need them as much as they need us. These little tiny tots have a lot to teach us. They teach us to love unconditionally. You also learn to have patience in the most stressed conditions and smile while you are almost about to drop. Yes, it is true they help us develop into human beings, the so-called superior creation of God. And gradually, they start getting better at almost everything and try to teach you to get better at things you once taught them.

Alhamdulillah, I feel like I have these precious gifts, who are also our answered prayers. Sometimes, I question myself, "What did I do to deserve them?". I am ever grateful to Allah for blessing me with this phase in my life called Motherhood.

item.title: Leadership Is All About Virtuousness
item.dc:creator: farajackus
item.content:encoded:
I'm not a business owner, nor am I a business coach. And I'm not here to give you lessons on leadership. I'm a simple girl, just like anybody else, who has worked with many people. And I have evidently seen the difference between managers and leaders. So, let me share my opinion about Leaders.

Just holding positions like a business owner, CXOs or VPs in an organization does not make someone a leader. It's not the positions that determine a leader, but its the leadership qualities. The virtues that evolve a person into a leader are honesty, courage, vision, compassion, care, fairness, selflessness, intellectual excellence, emotional quotient, creative thinking, and good timing. I know this is a lot to expect from anybody, so I feel there is no perfect leader. Leaders are people who fight with their inner demons and still manage to exhibit these qualities to the best of their abilities. 

Leaders are void of entitlement. It may be an old saying, but it fits in well here, " A diamond never screams out its value." Someone who fails to delegate or share the credit with other people can never become a leader. Yes, it's a tough job. When you have all the steps on your mind, and you see others not understanding it, even though you explain it multiple times. To trust anybody, to work on your vision or your brand is not easy. But a leader overcomes these insecurities by giving a safe space to their people. This safe space allows people to be themselves, absolutely vulnerable yet safe, to fail, be confident, feel motivated, and take ownership. 

Leaders will always be emotionally available to their people in some or the other medium, irrespective of their crazy schedule. Please don't assume that I'm writing all this from some management book. I have experienced all of this first hand. I've been lucky enough to work with such leaders who are excellent with their people management skills other than their expertise. And you'll be surprised to know that these are not some oldies, in their 60s with all the experiences in their life. Instead, they are young, passionate, and adorable leaders at Ajackus (my current company). I don't brown-nose my managers, but I couldn't help mentioning them while writing about leaders. 

Maulik Bengali, the CEO of Ajackus. Only when I explicitly spell it out do I realize that he is the CEO. He has made himself approachable and easy to that extent. This young man is responsible for making me fall in love with my work, and I look forward to working with him each day. He is an excellent example to the emotional availability I was referring to earlier.

Nirmal Topiwala, the CBO of Ajackus. He comes across as a very young, energetic, fun, and adorable youngster if you get a chance to meet him in person. But you'll not be able to find immaturity in his work. He is very organized and structured with his work. He has a lot of compassion and empathy towards his team. 

Rahul Jain, the VP of Engineering at Ajackus. He is a simple, "no non-sense" man. He has zero ego problems, which makes him pretty rare. He focuses on doing things the right way, irrespective of who is right. Though we are always there to pick up on each other (just for fun).

And other members in the leadership team and the teams I work with daily. Each one of them has been such a delight at work.  

But just because I'm writing about them doesn't make them perfect. At least, I will not claim that these young leaders exhibit the leadership qualities one hundred percent. Let's be realistic. We have difference in our opinions, argue with each other, things can get heated. Irrespective of all of this, I love working with them because they know how to take feedback. They can have mature and difficult conversations like a pro. They can accept it when they might be wrong. And, they are patient while they are right. Alhamdulillah, I feel blessed beyond measures to be working with these leaders.

Thanks for your patience. Love and peace.

item.title: Poverty - the worst form of violence.
item.dc:creator: farajackus
item.content:encoded:
Poverty is the inability of humans to create an institution of support system for their fellow mates on Earth. How many times in a day do we feel lucky or grateful for eating meals every single time we feel hungry? It may not even occur to us, that the food we take for granted can be a luxury for some people. We look for different cuisines and options, and fill full and don't mind wasting food.

One-third of the food in the world, 1.3 billion tons every year goes waste. Do we need all these stats to realize that we need to do something about the poverty that we witness so vividly? Is it only the responsibility of organizations like WHO to take care of these issues? Can't we do anything in our power to help poverty? Have we become so heartless that we feel nothing for people dying due to starvation? Millions of such questions keep hitting me with all their strength. We fight wars, play the power game, bomb populated places with nuclear weapons. So when tyrants do their thing, is there nothing we can do to save our mates on this planet?

I believe even having a nice meal while your neighbor might have been starving also counts as a barbaric act, it is not just the tyrants insensitively bombing all over the world. Don't you feel langar (meal) in Darga and gurudwara, meals in ISKCON temple, and other places of worship make sense in this scenario? It may not completely eradicate poverty. But these acts of generosity as a community shows us the way. A way in which every person can do a bit towards helping our planet get rid of this illness, called poverty. But feeding the starving people is just the first step. The next step to eradicate poverty is enabling people to lead decent lives. And the best way to do this is by education.

Education is a weapon that brings self-awareness. It is the best way to equip people with skills that can initially help them earn their living. But the role of education extends to teaching values like empathy, love, and compassion. These values are not luxuries but a necessity for the human race. And this is an achievable goal, and if we work towards it systematically, we can get rid of poverty from our wonderful planet. It's not like I have a full proof plan to eradicate proverty, but I do have a strong intentions. May God help each one of us to make such plans and execute them successfully.

item.title: Adolescence
item.dc:creator: farajackus

item.title: The Company Meet Up at Lonavala.
item.dc:creator: farheenza
item.content:encoded:
The level of excitement was so high that I woke up at 4 am as I had a morning flight. I reached the airport on time and found all my colleagues were already present. We started our journey by taking selfies. We were eight girls with one kid traveling together from Bangaluru to Mumbai for our meet-up. And how could we miss clicking our gorgeous city (Bengaluru)? It was thrilling to meet our team members from other locations at Mumbai's domestic airport for the first time.

We had an awesome time traveling on the bus for 3 hours. We played dumb charades and other games while traveling to Lonavala from Mumbai airport. On reaching our destination, I was stoked to see a lush green resort with amenities like a game room, banquet hall, pool, etc... It was an awesome break from the daily grind, where each one of us had a good, relaxing time filled with a lot of fun. We were given a chance to spend time with our teams. Where we played a lot of games and did some fun activities together. It was a quality time spent with our team. When I say "team" it refers to everybody at Ajackus, not just the ones we work with daily.

So, this meet-up was not just about fun and enjoyment. We had a festive "Rewards aNd Recognition" ceremony, where I wore a traditional saree. I also won an award for being "Curious" in the organization.

SURREAL is how I felt when I was offered a partnership at Ajackus. Regardless of how passionate you are about your work. It always motivates you more when people around you recognize and value your work. I feel my work is like a game filled with excitement and hurdles that challenge me the right way. Working with such awesome mates at work is a reward in itself. 

The management's vision to provide the best workplace for all the team members working hard for the organization is genuine and sincere. And that part touched me and strengthened my sense of belongingness and ownership of the organization.

And with a heavy heart, we had to bid adieu to everyone. I had such a great experience that I would cherish it forever.

item.title: Goa will fill you with unbelievable energy!!!!
item.dc:creator: farheenza
item.content:encoded:
Change always adds up spice to life. It could either be good or bad we need to harness it to have a wholesome life. But, when the change is refreshing from your daily grind it fills you up with immense energy. And what could be more refreshing than traveling with friends? And the icing on the cake is that we also kept working while we were on our vacation. So there was no FOMO(Fear Of Missing Out) at work.

It may sound like a cliche but it is actually true that a lot of people plan to go to Goa but only a few make it. We didn't really have an extensive plan, it was an impulsive decision. One of our friends (Nirmal) the mastermind behind the whole plan couldn't make it, due to some last-minute emergencies. But all of us suddenly just made up our minds and packed our bags.

It was quite an exciting moment for me as I was going to see both Goa and my office friends for the first time. Due to remote work, we had never seen each other physically before this trip. And, this was also the first time that I was going on a trip all by myself with my friends. With the protective family that I come from, I could have never imagined going all by myself with my friends to vacation. But luckily I'm married to my best friend, who has always encouraged me to live my life to the fullest. The only thing he was really concerned about was my safety, but he is very confident about me. And he also knew almost everybody in the office as he works in the same office too so he was at ease. He feels I can just do about anything on this earth if I make up my mind.

We booked our flights almost at the same time so we could stay together. To be honest, the adrenaline just rushed through my veins to meet my friends at the airport. Well, we got into the car and headed towards south Goa, specifically Agonda beach.

So, being a typical city girl from Bengaluru who hardly gets to see beaches the view of the Agonda beach was breathtaking, I was awestruck. I literally couldn't get my eyes off the wonderful waves and that cool breeze as I stood by the shack to watch it. I was suddenly transported into a whole new world. While my other friends were working to get us all rooms. The room you see in the picture above was my room.

The food at the shack was also lip-smacking, along the view of the waves made me feel surreal. And thanks to our bubbly little darling Bhavya, I got to play with the waves on the beach. We then decided to go on the boat ride just an hour before the sunset. And while the sun was setting we were still in the boat, I could just would sit in the boat and marvel at Allah's creation. The sunset was exquisite, no wonder writers often use sunset while describing a romantic scene.

Some more colleagues and friends later joined us, and there was a live performance in the shack that evening. Technically, that was the first time I had seen a live performance while having dinner and tried hookah under a friend's supervision. It might feel normal to a lot of people, but the family background I came from it was not at all normal. Basically, while growing up we were given all the freedom in things like our studies, choosing our college, the bike we wanted, or the person we want to get married to. But our elders are conservative in other things like traveling with friends or attending any live performance etc. So it was a totally out-of-the-box experience for me.

Just a day before we had to leave, while my body had gotten adjusted to the humidity and I no longer had to shower 4 to 5 times a day we traveled to north Goa. We visited our colleagues spend some quality time playing a lot of games and had a lot of fun. We then had been to the famous Baga beach, had dinner, and tried some crazy stuff like karaoke. Goodness!!! Trust me, I was not feeling any older than 18 years old. I was just having so much fun with all of my friends.

The next day when we had to leave, we were a little tight on schedule to catch our flight, especially my flight. But it was not me but Maulik who was all tensed, while I was having a fun time with girlies (Bhavya and Kinjal). Maulik took my luggage and rushed to the airport entrance and made sure that I didn't miss the flight. I was touched by this warm caring behavior of Maulik (literally like a family).

It has been more than a year since we did this, but it feels like it was just yesterday. My heart fills up with warmth and gratitude to everybody who made it to the trip and also to Nirmal who planned it. You guys have given me such wonderful memories that I'm going to cherish for the rest of my life.

item.title: When the going gets tough, the tough gets going
item.dc:creator: farheenza

The first time I came across this statement is when one of my biology professors in my 12th standard wrote this signed in my autograph book.

I didn't really understand that thought, well back then as much as I understand it now.

item.title: Talk by Richard Stallman
item.dc:creator: farheenza
item.content:encoded:
I was lucky enough to get a chance to attend a talk by the founder of Free Software Movement, Richard Stallman. He is a strong advocate of free software and hardware. His perspective of freedom in this digitally connected world, sounds like a refreshing breather. And his talk can really leave you questioning your lifestyle .

My first company that I worked for, Deeproot GNU Linux along with Reva Institute had organised this event. First of all I was feeling very excited and energetic to start off with as I was in a lush green college campus (one among my favourite places to hang out). And I was also feeling nostalgic as it has been quite sometime since I graduated from my college (GSSS Mysore).

Richard had a radical proposal for everybody to keep your personal data safe. I agree to the fact that he mentioned that we have chosen convenience over our freedom. And there is actually no privacy in anything that we do today. For example : Making an online payment, or shopping online, or allowing your phone applications to access your data. These are just some examples, but the point is that every time we do any such transaction our data is being used by these service providers for their benefit. These companies also monetize this data.

As I also consider myself to be a FOSS (Free and Open Source Software) girl, I could understand his sentiments. But practically, we are trapped with these online services in a way that we can't really have 100% freedom. We can only try to limit the usage of these services that are stealing all our data. We just have to choose wisely the limit of freedom we are ready to compromise.

Richard also urged the young people gathered there to join FSF(Free Software Foundation) as he feels that, there are many organizations that usefully promote free software, but no other organization stands for software freedom as firmly as the Free Software Foundation. And if freedom in your computing is important to you, he said please join the Free Software Foundation. People who are interested can check this website.

item.title: Ajackus - Oh what a journey!!!!
item.dc:creator: farheenza
item.content:encoded:
So, yesterday was my last day at Ajackus. It has been an energetic, fun filled journey for the last two years at Ajackus. In these two years I've had a huge learning curve. I've evolved both professionally and personally into something better.

My heart fills up with warmth and gratitude when I think about the time that I've spent here at Ajackus. To have a good manager is a boon, but to get an awesome mentor and a great friend in your manager is a jackpot. And that is what I got here at Ajackus. Maulik has been instrumental in guiding and mentoring me. He has always been pushing me to be my best. His ability to trust me with tasks, to give me creative freedom and a safe space to experiment with things and fail forward worked wonders for me. It has turned my insecurities at work into strengths making me a confident person. He used to often do a lot of brain storming with me and bounce off ideas that have for sure broadened my mental horizon. He was good at both giving and taking feedback.

Nirmal was another optimistic and a fantabulous person that I met at Ajackus. He has been a good mentor and a great friend too.

I also feel honoured and privileged to have worked with a team of smart and talented engineers Jyoti, Saurabh, Shubham, Hemanshu, Rucha, Piyush, Sneha, Shraddha, Monika, Lester and Rahul Thelkar. And also Anjan, though he recently moved out. They inspired me to be at my best every single day.

Last but not least our support team, Smita, Syed, Karuna and Sayli. They have always been ready to help with whatever issues I faced at work.

Overall, this has been an experience that I'll cherish forever. The opportunity to give webinars, to lead a campus recruitment drive, lead different types of clients and teams with different technologies, to forming and leading SMEs group. This has been an awesome learning experience.

With a heavy heart I bid adieu to all these lovely people yesterday. Looking forward to a new beginning. "Upwards and Onwards".

item.title: Onboarding at Walmart, an absolute delight.
item.dc:creator: farheenza
item.content:encoded:
If I had to put my journey of joining Walmart in one word, I would say " Overwhelming". As it is a huge organisation with thousands of associates, working in the Walmart Global Tech alone. But I am very lucky to have supportive manager, mentor who are ready to answer my never ending questions and guide me through my initial days.

At Walmart the core values that they operate on are held very close to heart by all associates. The core values are:

  • Service to the customer.
  • Respect for the individual.
  • Strive for excellence.
  • Act with integrity.

During onboarding the HR said that , we would see everybody act on these values. And that we would gradually start to act on them, too. I got to experience this first hand.

When you have your senior director make all the calls, and get things happening for you on your very first day. And calls you just to reassure you that you'll be taken care of, you know for sure that you've landed in the right place. And him putting in those efforts shows leadership in true sense.

We had a wonderful induction session by the HR. This was followed by a tour of spark square. It is an experiential learning centre that offers the associates a unique and immersive experience to learn about Walmart's history, culture. business, and innovation through exciting knowledge zones.

Within this 10 to 11 weeks of me joining Walmart, I have been able to meet a couple of leaders from US. There leaders were such a great influence on me. They were wonderful people who were extremely knowledgeable, but didn't make me feel intimidated as they were very down to earth. They were willing to get on 1 : 1 meetings with us and talk to us about any topic.

So, with a positive mind I set my sail into this huge but wonderful organisation.

item.title: Self love is actually self discipline
item.dc:creator: farheenza
item.content:encoded:
You might have heard of this phrase "self love" quite often these days. It is about prioritising and constantly focusing on improving ourselves. Just working towards getting better than what we were yesterday. Recently, I've realised that it's never too late to start practicing self discipline. All it takes is, to be patient with yourself. Have perseverance in the habit that you're trying to build.

We need to make good decisions for ourselves all the time. And these decisions should be followed up by actions. Earlier in the day I was watching Ryan Holiday's video about 10 stoic habits. And he mentioned in the video that everybody knows how to do it but only some people actually do it as they take action. So, stop putting off any of your actions for tomorrow.

And more importantly we need to stop waiting for the perfect time or place or situation. You've got "now" in your hands, so just give your hundred percent. You might not be good at something, but that should not matter. As humans, we are not born to be perfect at everything. So, be easy on yourself and consistently practice. It might look tough or nearly impossible in the beginning, but if you remain consistent you are going to achieve your goals sooner or later.

Now, let me give you my example. Three weeks back I decided that I need to stop thinking and start taking some action towards getting healthier and better. I chose to work on my physical, mental as well as emotional health. And this time I told myself that there will be days where I might miss certain activities. But that should not discourage me to move forward. This along with the concept of "failing forward" has helped me to be consistent so far.

One needs to realise that everybody is different, and not follow someone or something blindly. When you start your journey for self discipline, at least for a couple of months you need to be ready to experiment. Because, some things that work great for your friends or family may not work fine with you. Let me give you an example, I joined a gym three weeks back, and after a week I realised that working out in a gym is not my thing. I was looking for something different, sustainable and long term. So, I quit gym and started playing badminton along with small guided runs from Nike run club. I couldn't continue playing badminton as I didn't have a partner, everytime I wanted to play. But running stayed with me.

I definitely started off in a pretty shabby form. I could hardly run, I was rather jogging for a couple of seconds and walking for a minute. I definitely looked like a slow penguin trying to run. But after 5 days of running twice daily, now I can run a little faster and better. Though my form might still not look good. I've decided to stick to running and get better at this every single time.

The same goes with choosing your diet, you need to figure out what works for you. And you might have to try a couple of things before understanding what works best for your body. Likewise, your decisions to sleep early and wake up early are not at all easy habits but you've got to give yourself a little push and do it anyway.

I'm at my early stages of building self discipline. But I'm already in love with the whole process, because by just giving up on temporary gratification you can improve the overall quality of life. And also, it is a painful process. But if you train your mind to tolerate this momentary pain you'll be amazed at the way you overcome habits that were causing you to slow down.

So the benefits of having self discipline are you can get better spiritually, have more productive work hours, you can focus better, be creative, spend quality time with family, have a healthier body and mind etc. So go for it, and be happy.

item.title: Riding the Wave: The Power of the Adrenaline High in Productivity
item.dc:creator: farheenza
item.content:encoded:
Have you ever had one of those days when you're so busy it's exhilarating? Each task flies by in a whirlwind of focus, instead of feeling overwhelming, there's an actual buzz driving you forward. You're juggling multiple projects, participating in co-curricular activities at your workplace, tackling challenges at home, and you feel more attentive, more energized. That's an adrenaline high, and it's quite the productivity booster.

Adrenaline itself is a fascinating, dual-natured hormone. It's commonly known to fuel our fight-or-flight response during stressful or threatening situations. Yet, taking this chemical out of the emergency context and into our everyday hustle can lead to a thrilling and satisfying kind of busy-ness.

The Science Behind the High

Adrenaline, or epinephrine, is a hormone released by the adrenal glands. It jump-starts your heart rate, increases breathing, and priming your muscles for action. In essence, it's a temporary supercharge button for your body. And while this shot of energy was initially meant to protect us from predators, it can also rev up our productivity engine when we're dealing with looming deadlines and hefty workloads.

I realised this recently, when we had a number of competitions in Walmart Sports League, hackathon etc at the office. It actually made me more active, productive, happy and a satisfied person at the end of the day. As you would have done all of these activities along with completing your regular work. Another important and useful effect of this high is that you seldom have time to feel low or brood.

Harnessing the Power of Adrenaline

A properly channeled adrenaline high can ultra-boost your efficiency, helping you to stay alert, think faster, and work harder. But it's crucial to recognize that this isn't a state to be in perpetually. Too much adrenaline can lead to stress and burnout. Instead, think of it as a natural resource you can tap into sparingly an energy booster to use when needed. I'm grateful to the management at Walmart who facilitate and engage us in a way that we never feel boredom nor come close to burnout at work. My manager constantly keeps checking on me to make sure that I'm not pressuring myself into doing a lot.

Here are a few ways how you can harness and sustain this energy:

Embrace the Rush

When you notice that adrenaline surge, embrace it instead of panicking. Take a few deep breaths, orient yourself, and start attacking your tasks with renewed energy. The rush that you feel when you have a lot on your plate is actually good, if one can take it in the right spirit.

Prioritize

An adrenaline high can make you feel as if you can do everything at once, but remember to prioritize. Use this energy efficiently by completing high-priority tasks first. And yes, having a priority list for all the tasks that you plan to do always helps. That way you won't end up wasting your time.

Take Breaks

Although you may feel that you can work continuously, don't dismiss the importance of regular breaks. They help to maintain the balance of adrenaline in the body and prevent burnout.

Healthy Lifestyle

Proper nutrition and regular exercise promote good physical health, ensuring you can handle adrenaline rushes when they occur. Good sleep is also essential for maintaining stress levels and enabling your body to manage adrenaline effectively. Let me give you an example. We had a competition called "walkathon" at the office where we were tracking our steps for 21 days and as I took this competition seriously, now I'm in the habit of completing 15000 to 18000 steps daily irrespective of the weather, or situations. These walks are very liberating in nature and help me compose and organise my thoughts.

Practice Mindful Reflection

End the day by reflecting on what you've achieved. This will promote a sense of satisfaction and closure, winding down your adrenaline levels in a calm and controlled manner.

In conclusion, an adrenaline high pins you in the present, offering a intoxicating blend of speed, focus, and energy. So, the next time you find your schedule filled to the brim, remember: it's not a cause for alarm but an opportunity to ride that wave of adrenaline towards greater productivity and accomplishment. Happy busy-ness!

item.title: Learning curve of a software developer
item.dc:creator: farheenza
item.content:encoded:
Introduction:

Becoming a successful software developer requires continuous learning and adaptation. The process of learning and developing new skills in the field of software development can be challenging yet rewarding. One concept that holds significant importance for developers is the learning curve. Understanding the learning curve can help developers set realistic expectations allocate their time efficiently and enhance their overall success and growth.

Defining the Learning Curve:

The learning curve is a graphical representation of the rate at which one masters a new skill or concept over time. It illustrates the relationship between experience and performance. As developers encounter new technologies programming languages frameworks or tools they begin at the bottom of the learning curve gradually progressing as they acquire knowledge and become proficient.

Types of Learning Curves:

1. Steep learning curve: This type of learning curve indicates that acquiring a skill or concept is challenging and requires a significant investment of time and effort. Initially progress might be slow but as developers start grasping the fundamentals their proficiency increases rapidly.

2. Shallow learning curve: A shallow learning curve suggests that acquiring a particular skill or concept is relatively easier. Developers can quickly reach a level of basic competence but progressing beyond that may require more practice or exposure to advanced concepts.

Factors Influencing the Learning Curve:

Several factors affect the learning curve for software developers:

1. Previous experience: Developers may find it easier to learn and adapt to new languages or frameworks especially if they share similarities with their existing knowledge base. Prior experience in programming enhances the learning process.

2. Complexity of the technology: The complexity of the chosen technology impacts the learning curve. Sophisticated frameworks or intricate programming languages may require more time and practice to master resulting in a steeper learning curve.

3. Resources and support: The availability of quality learning resources mentorship and a supportive community can significantly influence the learning journey. Access to documentation tutorials online forums and developer communities helps developers overcome obstacles more efficiently.

Managing the Learning Curve:

1. Setting realistic expectations: Recognize that learning new skills takes time and effort. Set achievable goals and break them down into manageable tasks. Celebrate small victories along the way to maintain motivation.

2. Continuous learning: Embrace the mindset of lifelong learning. Stay up to date with the latest trends in software development and continuously seek opportunities to expand your skills and knowledge.

3. Hands-on practice: While theory is important practical application is crucial for mastery. Engage in projects or open-source contributions that allow you to apply what you've learned.

4. Seek guidance and support: Connect with other developers join communities attend meetups or conferences. Engaging with peers and experienced professionals provides valuable insights guidance and motivation.

Conclusion:

Understanding the learning curve is an integral part of every software developer's journey. Embracing the learning process and acknowledging the challenges it entails will lead to greater success and growth. Remember every step forward regardless of the curve's steepness brings you closer to becoming a proficient developer. Continuously learn practice your skills and leverage the available resources and support to overcome obstacles along the way. With perseverance and dedication you'll navigate the learning curve and excel in the dynamic field of software development.

item.title: When office echoes an Ivy School Ethos...
item.dc:creator: farheenza
item.content:encoded:
In the Silicon Valley of India, Bangalore, Walmart Global Tech stands as a hallmark of excellence, fostering an environment reminiscent of the venerable institutions of the Ivy League. This facility doesn't just prioritise technological advancements but also emphasises the nurturing of its associates, crafting a workplace that mirrors the enriching environment of top-tier educational spaces. Let's explore how the office culture at Walmart Global Tech embodies the spirit of an Ivy League institution.

Seeding the Future Through Continuous Learning

Just like Ivy League universities where learning is a continuous journey, Walmart Global Tech has established a culture that urges its employees to keep evolving intellectually. Knowledge-sharing sessions, workshops, hackathons, mentorship, well-curated courses, both online and offline classes, scope of moving to different departments and flagship events like converge are a regular feature, encouraging a dynamic exchange of ideas and fostering a spirit of collaborative learning.

Walmart Global Tech is replete with resources, offering boundless opportunities for exploration and learning. All the associates here have access to state-of-the-art tools and a plethora of resources, promoting an environment where innovation thrives, and no idea is unattainable. Our direct leader also came up with this amazing idea of master classes and did a mind blowing introductory interactive session with physical sticky notepads to get us into the groove of continuous learning.

An Oasis of Creativity

Ivy League universities are known for their breathtaking architecture and surroundings that inspire creativity. Walmart Global Tech's office space in Bangalore is designed with an aesthetic appeal, combining modern architecture with green spaces, thereby creating a nurturing habitat for innovation and inspiration.

Alongside technical events, there are also initiatives in place to promote physical fitness and overall happiness. This might seem like a lot of fun, but more often it is so much more than just fun for most of us. It is also a refreshing way of not letting yourself experience a burnout amidst the work pressure.

Spaces That Respect Individuality

Just as Ivy campuses offer quiet zones for introspection and scholarly pursuit, Walmart Global Tech recognises the need for solitary reflection, offering spaces that respect individuality and facilitate deep contemplation and strategic thinking.

Nurturing a Vibrant Community

Traditions play a pivotal role in Ivy League schools, binding individuals in a fabric of shared experiences and camaraderie. Similarly, Walmart Global Tech fosters a rich organisational culture, weaving traditions and rituals that bind its community, fostering a familial spirit that transcends professional boundaries. You will find most of the leaders who are top-notch both from India and the US are almost always willing to connect with you, too. Their kind, caring, witty, knowledgable, and fun company tends to bring out the best in you.

Well-being and Mentorship: Pathways to Excellence

Mentorship is a revered tradition in Ivy League institutions, paving the path for future leaders. At Walmart Global Tech, mentorship programs are in place, steering young professionals towards growth and grooming them to be the torchbearers of tomorrow. This helps the associates to get a clear view of the career ladder that they are trying to climb, and also helps them see the blind spots. And in case you feel stuck the mentors help you see the gap and that helps you to take the next steps for you to move to the next level in your career.

Holistic Approach to Well-being

Walmart Global Tech adopts an approach, that focuses on the well-being of its associates through initiatives promoting physical health, mental well-being, and a balanced work-life equation. We have sports leagues, competition on walking, cultural fests, and fun Fridays just like an Ivy League institution fosters holistic development.

Challenges

Does this mean that associates face no challenges and things are honky dory all the time. Definitely not. Just like in any other place, there are a lot of challenges and difficult conversations faced by the associates. The only difference is just like a top Ivy school there is a strong culture and there are systems and processes that help to ease the difficulties of associates. The associates are encouraged to reach out to any leader or HR in case they are having issues.

Conclusion

Walmart Global Tech in Bangalore isn't just a workspace; it is an ecosystem brimming with potential, a community fostering innovation, learning, and camaraderie, echoing the Ivy League spirit in its true essence. As it continues to evolve, the workspace stands as a beacon of excellence, nurturing not just careers but individuals who are ready to push boundaries, continually grow, and aspire to greater heights. It heralds a future where workspaces are not just about work but about cultivating individuals to their full potential, fostering a culture that is rich, vibrant, and deeply rooted in a spirit of collaboration and communal growth.

item.title: Strive for purposeful productivity instead of busy-ness.
item.dc:creator: farheenza
item.content:encoded:
A lot of times people glorify themselves and put the other person down who don't seem as busy as them at work. People most often don't understand that for a good performance at work they need to do purposeful and meaningful work.

There could be various reasons why some people are not as busy as others at the work place.

  • They might have meticulously planned their work in a way that they don't have to juggle all the time.
  • They might have some good habits like meditation or journaling that might be helping them.
  • They might be wired in a different way than others. They might have different priorities and goals in their life. For example after completing their tasks at work they might be interested in a lot of other things in life.
  • Deep learning and not always being in an execution mood may be their style.
  • Or they might have just been born lucky to stay as cool as a cucumber.


But I'm lucky that this doesn't cause a lot of damage at my workplace as we do have inspiring leaders who are smart enough to differentiate between busyness and result oriented productivity. For instance our senior director Pradeep Jain insists on us (future leaders) to always try and free our time. He encourages us to pick topics of our choices and learn. He encourages us to cultivate this learning and growth mindset. He never glorifies busyness, rather encourages us to aim at having result oriented initiatives at hand. All of this amidst maintaining hygiene at our regular work. And never underplays any opportunity where we could have some fun and action. Every session that I have with him, fills me with a lot of positive energy and has helped me set my immediate work goals.

"Under any circumstances, a leader who inspires is never judgemental." This was told to me by Rohit Chatter who is my mentor. Just this one statement from my mentor during one of our sessions has changed my way of responding to people. I have stopped reacting, and started pausing before I respond to anybody. On the other hand, when people stop judging others this whole toxic environment of putting someone down who doesn't seem as busy as you will not exist anymore. Rather, people will be more focused on improving themselves.

Firstly, it's pivotal to understand that productivity is an assessment of output, not input. Spending 'n' number of hours at your desk doesn't translate into effective work. It's about accomplishing tasks efficiently and skillfully within office hours. The key is strategic workload management. Prioritize tasks using methods like the Eisenhower Matrix or the Pomodoro Technique, breaking your day into focused sessions interspersed with short breaks. This approach prevents burnout and maintains a consistent performance level.

Popular culture glorifies multitasking, but neuroscience disagrees. Studies reveal that task-switching leads to increased errors and time wastage. Instead, mono-tasking, dedicating your attention to a single task at a time, enhances concentration and work quality. By mono-tasking within set time blocks, you're likely to accomplish more in less time.

There is another instance that comes to my mind when I think about prioritising an overwhelming amount of tasks on hand. We have a culture at our office where though we may not directly report to some seniors, we still gel well. They talk to us and give us insights and a lot of tips. They are so awesome sometimes they notice you feeling down, and without any hesitation walk to you and give you a quick pep talk. One among them is a senior of mine, Santhosh Kolur. He was the one to introduce me to the 80/20 rule. Though I read the book and love the rule. I'm still a novice at practising it (hoping to get better).

While modern tech tools are indispensable, they can also be intrusive. Manage technology wisely. Use applications that track and limit time spent on unproductive websites. Leverage collaborative platforms efficiently, setting boundaries by scheduling specific times for checking emails and attending meetings.

The glorification of overwork can stem from various sources: peer pressure, skewed reward systems, or personal apprehensions. It's a culture that celebrates being 'busy' as a status symbol. However, its vital to recognize that this not only compromises health and well-being but also impairs cognitive functions, leading to diminished work quality. Corporations and leaders need to dismantle this notion and instead foster an environment that equates productivity with smarter work ethics, not longer hours.

Incorporating physical activity, adequate hydration, and balanced nutrition during office hours can boost energy levels, concentration, and overall output. Office spaces designed with ergonomic furniture, good lighting, and perhaps a spot of greenery can create a conducive work environment.

Maintaining a clear boundary between professional and personal life is crucial. Overcommitting to work can strain relationships and personal growth. Design your work schedule so that it permits quality time for family, hobbies, and rest.

In conclusion, the true essence of being productive lies in the balanced orchestration of focused work sessions, healthy lifestyle choices, and personal time. By debunking the glorification of overwork and adopting a more holistic approach, individuals and organizations can ensure a healthier, more sustainable, and indeed, more productive work ethos. The future of work must be anchored in well-being, for it is in the richness of life, not the deprivation of it, that our best work is truly found.

item.title: Farewell Walmart
item.dc:creator: farheenza
item.content:encoded:
A Journey of Growth, Learning, and Cherished Memories

As I prepare to close this significant chapter of my career at Walmart, I am overwhelmed with a mixture of emotions. Reflecting on my journey here, I realise how transformative this experience has been, filled with opportunities for growth, learning, and building cherished memories that will stay with me forever.

Incredible Mentors and Leaders

The mentors and leaders at Walmart have played an instrumental role in my development. From day one, the unwavering belief in my abilities and the constant encouragement to innovate and strive for excellence shaped my professional journey. I was fortunate to have leaders who not only guided me but also challenged me to think critically and push my boundaries. This support system enabled me to grow both personally and professionally, and for that, I am eternally grateful.

Exceptional Colleagues and Team Members

One of the most rewarding aspects of my time at Walmart has been the opportunity to work with exceptionally talented colleagues and team members. Leading a team of dedicated professionals who put their trust in my leadership was an incredibly fulfilling experience. Their hard work, creativity, and dedication were the driving forces behind our successes. The camaraderie and support from my fellow engineering managers made our collective achievements even more special. The friendships and professional relationships built during this time are invaluable, and I will always treasure them.

Visionary Leaders and Inspirational Figures

Collaborating with visionary leaders was a highlight of my career. The complex challenges we navigated together and the innovative solutions we developed were both technically and personally enriching. These leaders' ability to inspire and guide was truly remarkable, and their mentorship left a lasting impact on my approach to problem-solving and leadership.

Innovative Teams and Collaborative Projects

Working with the Gen AI team was an eye-opening experience. Despite being a novice, their patience and expertise made my learning journey with new technologies like LLM both enjoyable and enriching. The collaborative spirit and the environment of growth and innovation they fostered were key to my development. This experience highlighted the importance of continuous learning and adaptability in the fast-evolving tech landscape.

Personal Growth and New Experiences

The opportunity to work on various projects with the teams was another significant aspect of my time at Walmart. These projects were not only technically challenging but also immensely rewarding. The dedication and expertise of the team made our projects successful and enjoyable, fostering an environment of creativity and innovation.

The support and dedication of our technical program managers and product managers were exceptional. Their kindness, patience, and personal touch in every aspect of our work made a significant impact on me. Their guidance and encouragement were a source of strength, and I am profoundly grateful for the opportunity to have worked with such dedicated professionals.

Cherished Moments and Personal Connections

The personal connections made during my time at Walmart are some of the most cherished aspects of my journey. From the early morning calls with colleagues in different time zones to the in-person interactions during visits to India, these moments were truly special. The willingness of colleagues to support and collaborate despite time zone differences demonstrated the strong sense of teamwork and dedication that defines Walmart.

Reflections and Future Aspirations

As I move forward, I carry with me the lessons, memories, and friendships forged during my time at Walmart. This journey has been filled with invaluable experiences that have shaped me both personally and professionally. I have learned the importance of resilience, adaptability, and continuous learning. I have grown not only as a professional but also as a person, thanks to the incredible people I have had the privilege to work with.

Leaving Walmart is bittersweet. While I am excited about the new opportunities and adventures that lie ahead, I will always look back on my time here with fondness and gratitude. The experiences and relationships I have built will continue to inspire and guide me in my future endeavors.

Thank you, Walmart, for making this chapter of my life so unforgettable. Heres to new beginnings and the exciting adventures ahead.

item.title: Not All Who Wander Are Lost
item.dc:creator: farheenza
item.content:encoded:
I can't help but feel like Lady Whistledown from Netflix's "Bridgerton" as I pen these words after a considerable hiatus. Writing is something Ive dearly missed while I've been occupied with settling into a new place. The thrill of sharing stories and updates with you all is truly unmatched.

It's always been my wish to explore new places, take on new challenges, and get exposed to different cultures and people from various geographical areas. However, like many Indian girls of my age, I completed my graduation, got married immediately, and soon after had babies one after another. I somehow juggled all these responsibilities, managing a career while also securing a place in my in-laws' hearts.

Then, when your eldest child hits their 13th birthday, it hits you hard. You realize that in the midst of all these events, you have almost forgotten yourself. As I approach my late 30s, this awakening is even more profound, prompting me to reflect on the dreams and aspirations I once had.

At this moment, it feels like a blessing in disguise to have a supportive husband who turns my dreams into our shared goals. Our children, eager to contribute, join forces to maintain our family's harmony and status quo, while allowing me the freedom to pursue my aspirations. Alhamdulillah, this fills me with immense joy and a renewed sense of purpose, making me feel like the happiest girl ready to conquer the world.

I believe every place has its own unique charm, with its own set of pros and cons. I prefer to embrace and enjoy the distinctiveness and experiences of different locations rather than being judgmental. For instance, while the extreme weather here in Dubai might be a shock for someone from Bangalore, I found joy in the hot summer, feeling as though it was an open sauna every time I stepped outside. I particularly appreciate the white sand here in Dubai.

Unlike many tourists who rush to see famous landmarks, I chose to live in an older area where I could experience life alongside the natives, as well as Indians and Pakistanis. There is a unique joy in maintaining a low profile, allowing yourself to learn, grow, and savor the little moments. Whether it's playing with kiddos at the park and beating them at badminton, meeting strangers during walks and getting to know them, or living in an apartment with girls from all over the worldAlgeria, Nigeria, India (Surat), Pakistan, and of course, Kerala.

One of the amusing aspects Ive noticed is that almost every other supermarket here is owned by a Malayali (people from Kerala). With a smile, the first thing they ask me upon seeing me is, "Are you from Kerala?"

One of our flatmates from Algeria recently prepared a delicious tiramisu. It was absolutely delightful! We often celebrate happy moments with little gestures like this. Happiness can stem from various reasons, whether it's cracking a job interview, someone getting proposed to by their partner, or someone receiving a promotion. These small celebrations bring us closer and make our shared experiences even more special. Apart from this I also used to have cousin's get together once on the weekends for a wonderful cup of ginger lemon tea with honey at a Cafe. The tea was honestly very good along with such good company used to brighten me.

But beyond all this, the most significant aspect is having the bandwidth to reflect and focus on yourself. When you're juggling multiple responsibilities, it's easy to overlook self-care. When you get an opportunity like this, the best way to leverage it, in my opinion, is to first conduct a thorough assessment of where you stand spiritually, mentally, physically, and emotionally. Then, systematically work on optimizing each aspect every single day.

There might be a latent creative streak in you that you've been putting on the back burner for a long time, and now is the ideal time to cultivate it. Reconnecting with your passions and interests can be incredibly rewarding, enabling you to grow and evolve in ways you may have previously underestimated.

Finally a lot of love and peace to all my readers.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Good to see you are writing again, nice to know you are enjoying your new experience and hope you find all that you are looking for in this journey.
